awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a High Resolution Low Voltage Electron Microscope for Multidisciplinary Needs at The University of Georgia
awd_abstract_narration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award supports the acquisition of a high-resolution low-voltage electron microscope at the University of Georgia (UGA) that enables the research, training, teaching, and outreach efforts of investigators across the physical sciences, geological and environmental sciences, biological sciences, engineering disciplines, and allied fields. The unique technical capabilities of this microscope allow the imaging and chemical analysis of samples under conditions that mitigate electron beam damage. These capabilities lead to the study of diverse materials including nanostructures, polymers, fibers, and biological specimens, which encompass research being done by 29 major users across numerous colleges, centers, departments, and laboratories at UGA. This instrument is integrated within the Georgia Electron Microscopy (GEM) core facility at UGA to permit inter- and transdisciplinary usage and collaboration. Beyond research applications and the associated training of student users, the new microscope enables the inclusion of state-of-the-art electron microscopy content in course offerings and outreach efforts. These activities are accomplished in part using GEM's Electron Theater, with an emphasis on nanoscience in the environment. In addition, the instrument is used to acquire data sets suitable for integration into K-12 STEM lesson plans.


This MRI award supports the acquisition of an electron microscope capable of low-voltage operation (defined as less than or equal to 30 kV). The technical highlights of this instrument include ultra high-resolution scanning electron microscopy (UHR-SEM) imaging at low voltages; high resolution scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) mode, including high-angle annular dark field (HAADF) imaging and additional detectors, all operating at a low beam voltage; and analytical tools that provide quantitative composition and structure data, including electron diffraction, elemental mapping by energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), and electron energy-loss spectroscopy (EELS), all at low voltages. Research projects enabled by this instrument span four thematic areas: (1) inorganic nanomaterials, especially 2D nanosheets and functional materials for energy storage, electronics applications, biomedical imaging, and drug delivery applications, (2) nanogeoscience and environmental soil science, (3) new frontiers in developing high-resolution low-voltage methods for imaging biological specimens, and (4) high-resolution low-voltage imaging of nanostructured hybrid systems and soft materials, including beam-sensitive samples like polymers and fibers. In particular, the application of electron microscopy to beam-sensitive materials will provide new detailed information about sample composition, heterogeneity, structure, phase purity, and properties at the nanoscale. Additionally, the superior contrast in STEM brightfield and HAADF imaging modes, compared with TEM imaging, will allow investigators to resolve detailed organic components, such as the ligand coronas of inorganic nanostructures and interfaces between biological structures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This Major Research Instrumentation project involved the acquisition of a high-resolution, low-voltage electron microscope to support investigators at the University of Georgia (UGA) and the regional Southeast in diverse disciplines spanning the physical sciences, geological and environmental sciences, biological sciences, and engineering disciplines, among others. The compelling research needs include the study of inorganic nanomaterials, materials in the nanogeosciences, beam-sensitive samples like biological specimens and polymeric soft materials, and developing new approaches and methods using low-voltage electron microscopy.

The specific instrumentation acquired was the Hitachi SU9000EA ultrahigh resolution FE-SEM/STEM microscope with energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS), and electron diffraction capabilities, along with several specialized sample holders (STEM tomography, in situ heating), and all required ancillary components. During Summer 2020, this system was installed on UGA's main campus at the Georgia Electron Microscopy (GEM) core facility in Barrow Hall. During Fall 2021, the system was moved to GEM's new facility featuring custom VC-E space in UGA's first Interdisciplinary STEM building. GEM also acquired a high-performance computer workstation to support EELS mapping and tomography work with data from the SU9000EA.

Instrument training and access, as well as routine maintenance, are managed by GEM's professional staff. During the award period, 22 student researchers (mostly graduate students) received hands-on training to operate the SU9000EA independently for basic imaging, EDS, and electron diffraction. These users are from UGA's Chemistry, Geology, Textiles, and Crop & Soil Science departments and the College of Engineering. Four of these individuals also received advanced training to conduct in situ heating experiments. To accomplish effective user training, resources were developed by GEM, including educational videos about the SU9000EA and electron microscopy that are freely available on GEM's YouTube site. GEM staff also collected data with the SU9000EA for researchers in UGA's Plant Biology, Physics, and Food Science departments, and the New Materials Institute.

Despite COVID-related challenges and interruptions related to the facility/instrumentation move during 2020-2021, this project's outcomes feature: (1) Research data from the SU9000EA incorporated in 7 published peer-reviewed journal articles during the award period, (2) Research results from the SU9000EA leading to fruitful collaboration with Oak Ridge National Laboratory scientists (4 approved user proposals to date with the Center for Nanophase Materials Science), (3) Establishing a strong and diverse user base for the SU9000EA at UGA as well as externally, including Georgia State University, Georgia Institute of Technology, University of Helsinki, Cornell, Colorado State University, and the USDA, (4) Student research focused on electron microscopy methodology, including one undergraduate and one master's student graduated during the award period, with additional M.S. and Ph.D. research projects underway. (5) Educational opportunities that integrate advanced electron microscopy in coursework, including in-person demonstrations for UGA classes in Food Science, Geology, Pharmacy, Crop & Soil Science, and GEM's First Year Odyssey seminar "UGA at High Magnification," (6) Numerous tours that showcase the SU9000EA and GEM's state-of-the-art electron microscopy facilities, including for the Board of Regents of the University System of Georgia, UGA's Franklin College Board of Advisors, and USDA officials, (7) GEM's next multiday workshop on low kV electron microscopy featuring the SU9000EA is planned for Spring 2023 to coincide with the Southeastern Microscopy Society's annual meeting being held in Athens, GA. These outcomes are expected to increase in quantity and quality over time as the user community continues to expand and use the data from the SU9000EA for publications and funding opportunities.

All the major goals of this MRI project have been achieved during the award period. The acquired SU9000EA enables research previously not possible at UGA and provides nanoscale chemical and structural information critical to understanding materials in diverse disciplines and vibrant interdisciplinary areas. Beyond this role as a research tool, the SU9000EA has become an integral part of GEM's educational and outreach activities.
